metadata.case_name: Collector of Customs v. Respondent (Walton Watch Company)

facts.text: Respondent carried on business as dealer in watches under name Walton Watch Company in Calcutta in 1963; had another premises wound up in 1955 with stock transferred to current business.
On March 19, 1963, Rummaging staff under appellants raided respondent's premises and seized 218 watches of foreign make.
87 watches released immediately on production of vouchers by respondent.
21 more watches released on September 18, 1963 and February 27, 1964 on production of more vouchers.
Customs authorities case: respondent unable to produce documentary evidence for rest of watches, hence not released.
Notice under s.124(a) served on respondent on March 6, 1964 to show cause why remaining watches should not be confiscated and penalty imposed.
Initial 6-month period under s.110(2) expired on September 19, 1963; no notice issued by then, respondent entitled to return of watches.
Appellants applied for and Collector granted first extension of 4 months on September 19, 1963 on ground inquiries at Bombay and Delhi pending; expired January 19, 1964.
Further extension of 2 months applied for on January 3, 1964; Collector granted on February 20, 1964, after expiry of first extended period.
Both extension orders passed ex parte without notice or opportunity of hearing to respondent.

Respondent filed writ petition under Art.226 in Calcutta High Court contending second extension invalid as proviso allows only one extension; first extended period expired without further extension by then; no hearing given.

Single Judge rejected contentions: proviso allows multiple extensions not exceeding 6 months each; power exercisable after expiry unless prohibited; no need for notice as sufficient cause to Collector's satisfaction; dismissed writ.

Division Bench of Calcutta High Court reversed Single Judge: held statutory obligation to return goods after expiry; right accrued to respondent on January 19, 1964 could not be defeated by later order; power quasi-judicial requiring hearing; second extension bad; s.124(a) notice vague; allowed writ, ordered restoration.

legal_issues.text: Nature of the power of the Collector of Customs under the proviso to the second sub-section of s.110 of the Customs Act, 1962.
Whether the Collector under that proviso can extend the period for giving notice under s.124(a) either after the initial period of six months or the extended period has already expired.

petitioner_arguments.text: Liability to return goods under s.110(2) not absolute, subject to extension up to one year total; no vested right until one year from seizure expires.
Proviso to s.110(2) does not contemplate notice to respondent as considerations for extension cannot be disclosed (public interest); only requirements: sufficient cause shown and within one year.

respondent_arguments.text: Proviso to s.110(2) envisages only one extension; second extension invalid.
First extended period expired January 19, 1964 without further extension; entitled to restoration; second order after expiry of no avail.
Extensions granted ex parte without hearing; Collector must decide judicially on sufficient cause, requiring opportunity to be heard especially after right to restoration vests.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s.110(2) Customs Act; principles of natural justice

respondent_arguments.text: No reasonable belief for seizure as only info was foreign manufacture; no info of violation.
Show cause notice under s.124(a) vague, no opportunity to explain.

court_reasoning.text: Power of seizure under s.110(1) based on reason to believe; proviso to s.110(2) uses 'sufficient cause being shown', requiring inquiry on facts by Collector; not subjective like seizure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference in language indicates proviso power necessitates determination on materials warranting extension.

court_reasoning.text: Collector expected to hold inquiry, not pass orders mechanically; burden on customs officer; function quasi-judicial or requiring judicial approach as affects civil right to restoration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Must give opportunity of hearing to person from whom goods seized to present pros and cons.

court_reasoning.text: Ex parte orders expose decisions to one-sidedness; supported by precedents like De Verteuil, Kraipak; distinguishes cases on 'reason to believe'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power not purely administrative; hearing required even before expiry as right involved.

court_reasoning.text: No apprehension of disclosing investigation; only fact of pending inquiries to be shown, not details.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature contemplated judicial approach balancing rights.

court_reasoning.text: First question answered in favour of respondent; extensions invalid for lack of hearing; restoration ordered; no need to decide second question or vagueness of notice.

holdings.text: Power under proviso to s.110(2) is quasi-judicial or requires judicial approach; opportunity of being heard must be given before granting extension.
Extension orders invalid; respondent entitled to restoration of seized watches.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narayanappa v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bangalore
precedents_cited.relevance: Satisfaction under 'reason to believe' not absolutely subjective; must be relevant.
Difference in language affects character of power (subjective vs. objective).
'Sufficient ground shown' implies inquiry and fair opportunity to be heard.
Quasi-judicial functions require fairness even if administrative; thin line between judicial and administrative.

precedents_cited.case_name: Regina v. Criminal Injuries Compensation Board Ex parte Lain
Sheikh Mohammed Sayeed v. Assistant Collector of Customs
precedents_cited.relevance: Held no hearing needed; SC disagrees as equates to 'reason to believe' cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Customs v. N. Sampathu Chetty
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Reason to believe' cases; not applicable to 'sufficient cause'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babulal Amthalal v. Collector of Customs
Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of Customs
Ganeshmul Channilal Gandhi v. Collector of Central Excise
precedents_cited.relevance: Held power administrative, no notice; SC disagrees.

statutes_cited.name: Customs Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs seizure, return of goods if no notice within 6 months (extendable), show cause notice; power under proviso quasi-judicial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition challenging extensions.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1909
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy for 'sufficient cause' in condonation of delay.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Division Bench of Calcutta High Court; held power under proviso to s.110(2) quasi-judicial requiring opportunity of hearing; extension orders invalid; ordered restoration of seized watches to respondent.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of seized watches to respondent

key_quotes.text: "The words sufficient cause being shown must mean that the Collector must determine on materials placed before him that they warrant extension of time."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of inquiry under proviso.

key_quotes.text: "An ex parte determination by the Collector would expose his decision to be one-sided and perhaps one based on an incorrect statement of facts."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Their Lordships are of opinion that in making such an inquiry there is... a duty of giving to any person against whom the complaint is made a fair opportunity to make any relevant statement..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes De Verteuil on implied hearing requirement.
